body: As a quick survey, standard output is line buffered in C, C++, Python, and Ruby. Go's `Printf` buffers output and writes it to an unbuffered stdout. Java doesn't document what it does, but `System.out` appears to autoflush.

I opened #23823. It's not _entirely_ clear to me that the solution isn't to just update the docs to point out that stdout in unbuffered, but I think at the point where you're invoking the `print*!` machinery you're sufficiently far from the OS that you probably just do want some output to appear in the terminal.
@richo The implementation of `std::io::Stdout` is definitely line-buffered. See https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/9f9e2516b41a63c4500f7cff1148de3ba05cc5cd/src/libstd/io/stdio.rs#L213

Sure, but that's orthogonal, since the underlying fd is not, and writing to it will not emit anything until it's flushed.

I'm pretty sure that the correct approach is to merge that patch, but figured it was worth pointing out that updating the docs may be a valid approach too.

It's not 100% clear to me that this is the behavior that we want. In https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/23087 it was explicitly removed due to worries about deadlocking. The specific problem of deadlocking can be papered over, but in general APIs tend to work much better over time if they do precisely what you expect, and it may not always be expected that `print!` flushes the output buffer.

One downside of flushing on `print!` would be that any form of "maximal buffering" when redirected to a TTY would be lost. For example C performs much more buffering when stdout is redirected than when it is to a console. This means that simple benchmarks which print information will be much slower in Rust than in comparison with others (due to the frequent flushing).

I would be fine beefing up the documentation in this regard, of course!

That's totally reasonable, and mostly what I expected. Do you have a
citation about the c buffering though? That wasn't be belief and I'd love
to read more.

While making the documentation clearer would certainly be helpful, I think Rust is losing ease of use by making auto-flushing more difficult than need be. C++ has [`std::unitbuf`](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/manip/unitbuf) to making auto-flushing simple in cases like prompts and progress bars. This at least makes it so that users don't need to call `flush()` explicitly after every call.

> This means that the print! macro does not act like a println! without the newline as the documentation suggests.

`println!` macro, on the other hand, does not specify anything about its flushing semantics either. Even the `std::io::Stdout` doesn’t and totally should.

---

I generally really dislike implicit flushing and prefer to flush explicitly. On the other hand, there’s `write{,ln}!`, which does not and can’t assume anything about buffering, so I’m ambivalent about this issue.

> If print! were to auto-flush, then it would deadlock the current process because the stdin handle was already locked. The alternative here is adding one call to try!(locked.flush()) right above the call to read_line.

I think you misunderstood what the issue is about: it is only proposed to flush std_out_ after `print!` writes to the std_out_. i.e. change

``` rust
macro_rules! print(…) {
     …
}
```

to 

``` rust
macro_rules! print(…) {
    …
     stdout().flush()
}
```

Since `print!` already takes a lock to write, this change will not introduce any more new cases where it deadlocks. For example snippet below deadlocks currently and will deadlock in all the same cases if we made it to auto-flush.

``` rust
let output = io::stdout();
let output = output.lock();
print!("stdout locked"); // deadlock.
```

I’m starting to believe that stabilising `Std{in,out,err}::lock` was a wrong and hasty move.

> I think you misunderstood what the issue is about: it is only proposed to flush stdout after print! writes to the stdout

Hm yes, I think I have misunderstood! There are definitely performance considerations which affect flush-on-all-print semantics as it's not something that other languages tend to do and can greatly hinder various benchmarks.

I think the crux of this is basically "What is the intent of print!". My
intuition is that it's not intended to be in the critical section, and is
instead meant to be a helper for "make this string appear on stdout", I
could really take or leave whether or not it flushes. That said,
considering that it already traverses all of the formatting machinery
anyway, if it can't deadlock my intuition is that the flush is just one
extra syscall to make this do something more user friendly/intuitive.

While I don't believe it's actually on the table, I would be a stoic -1 to
any suggestion of making all stdout writes autoflush.

I think it's fine that `print` doesn't flush as long as stdout is flushed on exit, which is the case. My intuitive understanding of invoking `print` in any language is that you're building up some output incrementally, in which case you don't really want to flush.

As I mentioned earlier, most other languages have an easy way to print a line with a newline that also flushes. C++ has the `stdout` that flushes on `stdin`. Python has `print("foo", end='')`. Ruby as `print` and easy auto-flushing.

Also, given the similar naming, I think `print!` and `println!` should have the same behavior with the exception of printing a newline.

If you're building up output incrementally and you're fine with buffering, then why not append to a `String` and then just print that or use `.write`?
We register at_exit handlers for stderr and stdout that should flush them: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/libstd/io/lazy.rs#L54 but they may not be running in all situations?

Let’s put it this way: there are, basically, two very common use-cases for `print!`:
1. Output of complex lines.
2. Input prompts.

If it does not flush, then 1 is ok, but in 2 we get confusion. If it does flush, 2 is ok and in 1 we get performance issues.

For me personally confusion seems to be a lot worse than (not that huge) performance degradation, which, by the way, can be worked around in a number of ways.

AFAICT currently the behaviour of C, i.e. the default buffering policy (as per the setoff documentation) is respected. At least on Unix-like systems this means that printing a newline flushes when writing to a terminal. @tanadeau is this what you were looking for?

In general, this looks like a reasonable compromise to me, as non-interactive input gets good performance thanks to buffering, while interactive programs show each line as soon as it is complete.
I believe that the only issue with this might be with in-line prompts.

An even better approach could be to make `flush` more permissive. Multiple threads writing to `stdout` can lead to interleaved meaningless output if care is not taken (basically by ensuring sequentiality of the writes), such problem does not affect flushing. I think that the old approach of flushing `stdout` upon a `stdin` read would ensure the most obvious behaviour for interactive programs and preserve performance for non-interactive programs.
If this (flushing without locking) looks like an acceptable approach, I would be willing to implement it.
Fishing `stdout` on a `stdin` read would solve the issue. That makes in-line prompts work as expected in C++ as the test code I had earlier shows.

The intended function of `print!()` is to display a string on the command line. Having to flush the buffer to display what I want feels counter intuitive and absolutely feels to be pushing against the purpose of the macro. This function fulfills basic functionality and should behave the way I expect, without any 'gotchas'.

`print!("x")` should be "Display x to the screen".
`write!(io::stdout(), "x")` should be "I'm building something up. Don't force a flush"

I'm in favor of **_not flushing `print!()`_** as part of the macro.

Don't get me wrong!  **I totally understand where the for-flush guys are coming from!** I felt the same way about flushing in the first languages I learned.  So, I don't have any animosity or anything.

Let me try to convince you that you *don't actually want `print!` to flush!*  The current behavior is elegant, loosely coupled, and well-designed.  Also, I have some suggestions!  They are after the argument.

Case Against Flushing in `print!`
----

- **Flushing violates expectations.**†  `stdout` is line-buffered. It would be **unexpected** for a macro that "_uses the `format!` syntax to write data to the standard output._"‡ to also change the behavior of `stdout`.  Being line-buffered means that data is buffered until either a newline has been seen or a large-enough amount of data has been buffered, either of which causes the data to be flushed.
  _†The expectations of those who understand `stdout`._
  _‡Quote [from the docs](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/macro.println.html)_

- **`println!` also does not flush.**  Wait, what!?  Don't believe me?  [Check for yourself](https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/std/macros.rs.html#121-125)!  Once again, `stdout` is controlling the behavior.  `stdout` sees a newline _and decides to flush_, but `println!` just "_uses the `format!` syntax to write data to the standard output._"

- **Loose coupling has benefits.**  `print!` and `println!` are [loosely coupled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loose_coupling) to `stdout`, which is part of my claim that the design is elegant.

- **Knowing that stdout is line-buffered is valuable.**   By extension, anything that gently leads you to that knowledge is also valuable.

- **Current behavior mirrors other languages.** I will concede that "doing it the way everyone else does" is often a lousy reason *by itself*, but it can be a great addition to a list of other reasons! 😉 Several of the languages I have used do exactly the same thing...make their `stdout` line-buffered, and then have a way to print _with_ a newline that ends up getting flushed, and a way to print _without_ a newline that ends up not getting flushed.  For me, I absolutely expected the output of`print!` **not** to be flushed when I learned it did not add a newline to the message.

- **Already mentioned stuff.**  Other stuff mentioned above by others already in this thread.

But the PAIN is REAL! (aka Suggestions)
----
Yes, it is!  I know the pain is real!  I know exactly what it feels like to look at your program and wonder "where the heck is my output?"  I probably did it three dozen times before I **finally** caught on to How Things Really Worked(tm).  It's a real thing that most real programmers that I know go through (except those super-brilliant guys who "just get it" the first time they read something, but lets ignore them, because sometimes they need to be ignored for the rest of us to stay sane. 😜 )

Here are some things that could be done *in the language implementation/docs*:

- **Explain it in the macro docs.**  The docs for `print!` and `println!` could mention in a relevant way that actual flushing is done by `stdout`, which is line-buffered, and then **link to the page for `stdout`** right there.  Wait!  Wait!  I'll actually give some suggested text:

> Due to the default line-buffered nature of [std::io::Stdout](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Stdout.html), each call to `println!` will normally end up being flushed immediately.

> Due to the default line-buffered nature of [std::io::Stdout](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Stdout.html), calls to `print!` will not normally be flushed immediately.

- **Add line-buffering behavior language to the docs for [std::io::Stdout](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Stdout.html)**  This behavior isn't mentioned in the docs.  It should be!

- **Make a more flexible macro/function/object.**  Or in other words, "Go back to the drawing board."  As a concrete example, in the Python community for years I observed this same pain-point with their `print` *statement* implementation.  By default, Python's `print` *statement* includes a newline (so the output gets flushed) unless you end the statement with a comma, which causes the newline to be omitted (which meant the output suddenly stopped flushing, unless you included your own newline).  First they addressed this through documentation of behavior (which helped a lot), but there was no decent way to actually add an optional way to override behavior.  BUT, when the time came around that they decided to add a fancier `print` *function* to version 2.7/3.x, they addressed this pain point by giving the function an optional argument that would also explicitly flush.  The combination of documentation plus an easy-to-remember, convenient way to force flushing seems to have done a good job at addressing that pain point.  I don't know if an analogous behavior could be implemented in Rust macros.  I know functions don't support optional arguments (will they ever?).  But if it could be done somehow...fantastic!  Maybe it means taking an entirely different approach to the idiomatic way to print to stdout.  I dunno.

- **Make an additional macro.  Maybe `print_and_flush!`** Sorta clunky, but at least intent would be very clear.

- **Make a `flush!` macro.**  Enough said.

----

Here are some things you could do *in your own code*:

- **Write your own macro.**
```rust
// placeholder for a nice macro you can copy-and-paste - help me out here, someone
```

- **Make a helper function.** If you happen to be dealing with all string literals, or really similar formatting, it might be just as convenient to just write your own helper function that also flushes.  Here is a pretty nice starting point you can copy-and-paste:

```rust
fn printflush<S>(msg: S) where S: Into<String> {
    print!("{}", msg.into());
    std::io::stdout().flush().unwrap();
}
```

- **Bite the bullet.** Add this line wherever you want to flush.

```rust
std::io::stdout().flush().unwrap();
```

Deadlocking is certainly possible and always will be. If we begin flushing implicitly, the code, which relies on `stdin` operations to not take a lock for `stdout`, will break.
@nagisa why is locking required for flushing? Concurrent writes needs mutual exclusion to avoid races, but it is not obvious that flushing requires locking as well.

Hey, I just hit this too!

Maybe a sufficient compromise that would make everybody reasonably happy is just a `prompt!()` macro which behaves like `print!()` but flushes? I'd be happy to have such a macro, which would solve the most common case. Add it to the *Guessing Game* tutorial and everybody will notice it.

I'd prefer that `print!()` and `println!()` flush when `stdout()` is a tty. I can't imagine caring about the slight performance hit in this case, and the multi-thread race and [maybe] deadlock conditions are endemic in trying to `print!()` from multiple threads anyhow. But I'll settle for an extra macro if that's what it has to be.

I feel that some of the confusion comes from the fact that `stdout` is line buffered. Flushing is entirely up to the buffer and depends on the value of its content at runtime. It is implicit and left out of not only `print!` and `println!`'s semantics but also `write!` and `writeln!`'s. This, I find, is contrary to Rust's culture of explicitness and orthogonality.

A solution would be to make `stdout` a normal buffer:
* `print!` and `println!` explicitly call flush and do what you expect: paint on screen. Behavior is mostly the same as today, minus the sometimes missing text with `print!` that surprises newcomers.
* `write!` and `writeln!` can be used to build output. Flush must be called manually and we could now buffer multiple lines of text without triggering a flush, which we can't do today without allocating another buffer/string. (We may or may not want to create `write_out!` and `writeln_out!` macros that do not bypass `LOCAL_STDOUT` the way `write!` and `writeln!` do.)

Line buffering has its uses, but I feel like it's trying to be smart but it's really just making things more complicated.

Sorry. But my *How can I* question arouses out from the decision not to flush `stdout` neither after `print!()` nor before `read_line()` calls discussed here. And I utterly comprehend the former (locking console for flushing any unfinished line would slow down performance without real need), but am still very disappointed with the latter.

Constructing complex output by multiple sequential `print!()` calls is a common task for text-based programs. Flushing every output is not necessary in this case, it should be done only at the end of such a sequence. No confusion can emerge.

Another common task is interacting with the user, and the Guessing Game is a good example (a less naughty example is Rust's installer for Windows). Such a task can duly interleave the program's output with the user's input and it seems a good practice to grant the programmer a proper tool for it. Using something like print() and read() functions seems to be the solution, but with Rust it is an illusion: the programmer is obliged to bother with flushing unfinished lines of `stdout` before every read.

So why this flushing should not be seamlessly placed before every read inside Rust library? It seems obvious that before reading the user's input all the program's output ought to be flushed: the user has to see what [s]he asked for. Apropos, if the library flushes `stdout` at every new line, why it does not before every read?

Or, if there is other proper practice of interacting with the user - which is it? Using strict `println!()` vividly resembles me old good BASIC times.

Whence my "How can I...?".

I fully agree with @BartMassey's conclusion above except that I emphasize the only place for flush is not after writing but before reading user's input, which is very slow by nature, where there is plenty of time to do anything useful.

@BartMassey, thank you for example and explanations! I feel the issue is still not settled.

> the only place for flush is not after writing but before reading user's input, which is very slow by nature, where there is plenty of time to do anything useful.

There are other places where some kind of convenient flush would be useful. One example is printing some non-line-terminated string before an expensive computation.

```Rust
print!("The answer is  (please wait)... ");
println!("{}", expensive_function());
```

I'm not too dogmatic about what's done about these cases, but I feel like at least one of the solutions proposed above should be implemented.

We discussed this with the libs team and our feeling was that none of the suggestions that involve an implicit flush really address the knowledge gap of people having an incorrect (or no) mental model of how buffered i/o and flushing works. These changes would just move the stumbling block to some later point when buffered i/o and flushing inevitably bites them anyway. People writing interactive command-line apps *need* to understand what flushing means and inserting implicit flushes would not be doing them any favors.

We would welcome documentation improvements that do a better job of teaching the behavior of std::io with respect to flushing.

Also we would love to consider an [RFC](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/libs_changes.md) for improving the ergonomics of explicit flushing in conjunction with `print!` or other uses of std::io. In particular, we agree that the current approach of `use std::io::{self, Write}; io::stdout().flush().expect("Could not flush stdout")` is not the best -- but just condensing it into something like `flush!()` isn't obviously better either. Looking forward to what people come up with!

I just ran into this issue for the first time, and just to give my two cents: I generally agree with what's been said.

`println!` flushing is fine, because when you're done with a line, you're done with a line. On the other hand, in my experiments across various languages, I've generally reserved `print!` and its relatives in other languages for times where I need to assemble a single line to print, but don't necessarily need to have it flush at separate times, in which case yes, not having a flush is largely irrelevant. I believe that `println!` and `print!` should be kept alone.
For the people that want C-style buffering, why not create a `printf!` macro?
This time, the `f` refers to `flush/force`, meaning you **will** see the data immediately.
This has the advantage of being backwards-compatible, as all existing code using `print!` will be fine.
For the people that are okay with a performance hit and just want unbuffered printing, `printf!` should do fine.

(Also, having a `printlnf!` macro is a bad idea, because most people will mistake `printf!` for the C version. Having them mistake it for the C version is good, because it _should_ be like the C version, anyways.)
The macro names I am currently using in my draft RFC are `prompt!`, `eprompt!` and `input!`. Bikeshed away… I'll try to post a draft Real Soon Now, I promise.

+1 for a python-style input! macro, which takes care of the typical write-then-read case.

> Sounds good! Should we remove the implicit flushing in `println!()` as well?

It's worth noting that technically `println!` doesn't flush. You can see in the [source code](https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/std/macros.rs.html#153-157) that it simply calls `print!` with an appended newline. Rather, it's the [current implementation of stdout](https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/std/io/stdio.rs.html#341-346) which unconditionally line buffers, regardless of whether stdout is a tty or not. In fact, it's called about explicitly as a `#FIXME` in that code that the buffering behavior should be smarter; that change would implicitly change the flush behavior of all the macros that use it (print, println, and anything built on them).

>[Making print!() flush] would just move the stumbling block to some later point when buffered i/o and flushing inevitably bites them anyway. People writing interactive command-line apps need to understand what flushing means and inserting implicit flushes would not be doing them any favors.

I only have a shallow understanding of how flushing works, so please forgive the question. How will people be bitten? My guess:
 - The application will be slower.
 - If a message is split between multiple print!() statements, a partial message will appear on screen, quickly followed by the message tail.

Is there anything else? These issues seem trivial when I weigh them against the panic and frustration of "I'm printing stuff but it doesn't appear on-screen." > what is the difference between `print!` and `write!`? aren't they basically the same?

They are basically the same; `write!` allows you to write to any stream, whereas `print!` specifically writes to stdout.

Just to add my 5 cents, I think `print!` should not flush because line-buffered output is the expected behavior, but
1) there should be a version of the print macro that explicitly flushes; and
2) stdlib functions that read from stdin should first explicitly flush stdout.

> As a quick survey, standard output is line buffered in C, C++, Python, and Ruby. Go's `Printf` buffers output and writes it to an unbuffered stdout. Java doesn't document what it does, but `System.out` appears to autoflush.

Note that the C and python behaviour (at least on Linux) is a bit more nuanced: It is line buffered when stdout is a terminal, and 1kB block buffered otherwise.

For processing large text files (either in a pipeline or writing to a file), the "unbuffered when not a tty" can make a huge performance difference (e.g., two orders of magnitude).
